course.subject: IELM
course.name: Computing in Industrial Applications
course.description: Introduction to microprocessor technologies and computer hardware with industrial applications. Computer systems for industrial control. Digital communication, mobile computing and RFID technology.

reviews.author: yeungck213
reviews.title: Summary
reviews.comment_content:
It is an Project-based course. No lecture. The project is about a real industrial case. Groups are not assigned.

There are 2 short assignment in the beginning of the term. Remaining submissions are all related to the project.   

It has a official tutorial time.
However, it is not compulsory. Groups can decide when to meet up.
reviews.comment_teaching:
No official lecture is needed.
It is mainly a self-learning course.

However there was 2 sessions for you to meet up with the professor for Group performance evaluation. Each session only takes 5-10 mins.
reviews.comment_grading:
Good grading.
It is not graded by the result of your project but the learning outcome and the process.

So, pay more effort on your individual learning portfolio and project report

Course grading:
Written Assignments1 (6%)
- Assignment One 2%
- Assignment Two 4%
Project Reports (35%)
Project Realization (23%)
Learning Portfolios1 (22%)
Course Participation1 9%
Peer Evaluation1 5%
reviews.comment_workload:
You should have an idea in your mind that you have to work overnight before the demonstration.
Quite a frequent group meetings and be careful of free rider teammates.

reviews.author: vs
reviews.title: Useful + a lot to learn if you come from a zero-hardware background
reviews.comment_content:
This course is self-paced and project-based, which means you'll act as "consultants" (don't worry, there's not much you need to do) for a manufacturing / industrial firm and create a solution from scratch.

For us, the task was to design a conveyor belt solution for different types of baggage for use at the Hong Kong Intl Airport. Entailed use of sensors, motors, pneumatics, PLCs / MCUs etc -- "simple" electronics concepts that would normally be taught in lecture form.

Students are divided into three groups of five, most of which are IE majors, and compete against each other for the title of best innovation. There is a roadshow towards the end of the course where you present and demo your prototype in front of profs / industry professionals.

You learn by doing (for instance, YouTube vids / ordering your parts by yourself / from friends and peers and teammates) and inquiring and asking
reviews.comment_teaching:
There is no traditional teaching per se, but you have access to labs + all teaching material from the non-experiential course, which the prof has been teaching for a long time.

Prof is quirky, has his myriad teaching philosophies, very innovative and open to ideas. He's a cool dude if you actually sit down and talk things out, but usually is too busy for that. Eccentric, but I guess that comes with most types of "genius"
reviews.comment_grading:
You're graded on your prototype, individual learning portfolio (in the form of slides / word processed doc), peer assessment, instructor interviews. There's also a site visit to HACTL at the Hong Kong Intl Airport cargo handling division

Absolute grading, most people get at least a B
reviews.comment_workload: As with most hands-on projects, the more time you spend in the lab, the better your end product. Most students ended up spending hours in the lab, some of them slept over at night / weekends, during crunch time (1 - 2 weeks before showtime)
